entry.title: How Sally Ride blazed a trail for women in space
entry.summary:
Sally Ride sits in the aft flight deck mission specialist's seat during deorbit preparations. On June 18, 1983, Sally Ride became the first American woman to fly in space when the space shuttle Challenger launched on mission STS-7. As one of the three mission specialists on the mission, Ride played a vital role in helping the crew deploy communications satellites, conduct experiments, and make use of the first Shuttle Pallet Satellite. In June 1983, this barrier-breaking astronaut overcame discriminatory policies‚Äîand a sexist society‚Äîas the first American woman to launch into orbit.
On June 18, 1983, Sally Ride would become the first American woman to launch into space. She had already survived NASA's grueling training and a barrage of tests, but there was another hurdle to cross ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Earth‚Äôs Most Interesting Animals
entry.summary:
Before your visit, discover some of Earth's most captivating creatures found at the San Diego Zoo Safari Park, like the stealthy Sumatran tiger, the soaring California condor, and the resilient desert tortoise‚Äîeach with its own fascinating traits that you can observe during your safari adventure.
The southern white rhino, nearly 99 percent of which are found in South Africa, Kenya, Namibia, and Zimbabwe, is one of the largest land animals on Earth, second only to elephants. Despite the name, these rhinos are gray, and "white" was likely derived from the Afrikaans word for "wide," referring to their broad, square mouths. These semi-social animals often live in groups; males are usually solitary and mark their territory with dung. White rhinos are grazers, and enjoy rolling in mud‚Ä¶

entry.title: ‚ÄòThis is not just ice‚Äô: Glaciers support human livelihoods, UN deputy chief says
entry.summary: UN Deputy Secretary-General Amina Mohammed called for urgent action to protect water-related ecosystems in remarks to the International Conference on Glaciers‚Äô Preservation in Dushanbe, Tajikistan, on Friday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN‚Äôs lifesaving programmes under threat as budget crisis hits hard
entry.summary: The UN is facing a deepening budget crisis that threatens lifesaving operations worldwide. From refugee aid in Mozambique to maternal health services in Afghanistan, critical programmes are on the brink of collapse unless urgent funding is secured.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: ‚ÄòJustice is long overdue‚Äô: Guterres calls for reparations for enslavement and colonialism
entry.summary: Secretary-General Ant√≥nio Guterres renewed his calls for Member states and the United Nations to work towards justice and reparations for Africans and the diaspora in a speech in New York on Friday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: World News in Brief: Education suffers amid DR Congo violence, WHO greenlights RSV vaccines, more hurricanes ahead for Haiti
entry.summary: In Ituri, a province in the east of the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC), intensifying conflict, intercommunal violence and mass displacement are forcing hundreds of thousands of children out of school.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Songs of hope rise from Gaza‚Äôs ruins
entry.summary: In Al-Jundi Al-Majhool Square ‚Äì once the bustling heart of Gaza City ‚Äì music now floats among the tents. The square, transformed into a sprawling displacement camp, shelters hundreds of families driven from their homes by more than 19 months of war.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Flavoured nicotine products driving youth addiction, WHO warns
entry.summary: For most nicotine users today, their first experience with the drug is a flavoured product ‚Äì making it easier, and more appealing, to try.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza is the ‚Äòhungriest place on earth‚Äô, as Israel continues stranglehold on aid
entry.summary: Starving Gazans continue to be deprived of aid as international relief efforts are being severely constrained by the Israeli authorities, the UN humanitarian affairs coordination office OCHA said on Friday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: How to plan the ultimate island-hopping adventure in Croatia
entry.summary:
Whatever you‚Äôre looking for, you‚Äôll find it in Croatia's islands ‚Äî from buzzy resorts for a party crowd on Hvar to towns like Korƒçula or Rab, their streets an insouciant jumble of gothic and Renaissance beauty. In between are endless pine-scrubbed specks with no firm grip on the 21st century, washed by the cleanest waters in the Mediterranean. Known as the land of a thousand islands, Croatia‚Äôs Dalmatia and Kvarner archipelagoes offer an abundance of coastal adventures ‚Äî from exploring a little-known National Park to swimming in a cave plucked from Odyssean legend.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
The fascination of islands is that they appear to be distinct, self-contained worlds. If that‚Äôs true, then Croatia is practically its own solar syste‚Ä¶

entry.title: Why some people struggle to form mental images
entry.summary:
Close your eyes and imagine an apple.
Can you see its shape? What color is it? Is it floating in the air, or being held by a hand, or sitting on a table?
If you find yourself struggling, you might have arecently coined condition called aphantasia.¬†
People with aphantasia, or ‚Äúaphants,‚Äù say they lack the ability to effectively visualize in their mind‚Äôs eye. They might have vivid imaginations, and lead very creative lives, but their brains work a little differently when it comes to visual imagery.
Twenty-five years ago, Adam Zeman, a professor of cognitive and behavioral neurology previously at the University of Exeter, now an honorary fellow at the Centre for Clinical Brain Sciences in Edinburgh, was introduced to the curious case of a man who had lost the ability to vis‚Ä¶

entry.title: Where to stay in Porto
entry.summary:
The Yeatman is one of many unique accommodation options in the Portuguese city of Porto. Portugal‚Äôs second city is riding a wave and its hotel scene is equal to the task, with wine-themed haunts up to palatial pads.


This article was adapted from National Geographic Traveller (UK) In a city dominated by independent hotels, Porto offers a plethora of unique and interesting boutique places to stay. From converted warehouses and 19th-century palaces to properties in and around the famous wine district, you‚Äôre ne‚Ä¶

entry.title: Who was Sacagawea? The real story of her life and legacy
entry.summary:
Explorer Sacagawea stares into the distance while Jean Baptiste Charbonneau sleeps soundly on her back. She was vital to the Lewis and Clark Expedition after the Louisiana Purchase. Often remembered merely for guiding Lewis and Clark, Sacagawea‚Äôs story is far more complex. Discover the deeper story behind the life of this Shoshone woman‚Äîbeyond the expedition.
Of all the figures that emerged from the¬†American West, none may be so wrapped in mythology as Sacagawea. When she joined Meriwether Lewis and William Clark's infamous expedition west, she was just a teenager and a new mother. However, Sacagawea emerged as an icon of the New World.
Today, her name is synonymous with a period characterized by rapid westward expansion at the great expense of the Tribal Nations who stewarde‚Ä¶

entry.title: Inside Chile's wild and beautiful Juan Fern√°ndez Islands
entry.summary:
On a recent visit to Chile's Juan Fern√°ndez Islands, National Geographic photographer Andy Mann found himself surrounded by hundreds of playful locals: endemic Juan Fern√°ndez fur seals. Once thought to be extinct, the seals are believed to number more than 200,000, far exceeding the islands' human population of under a thousand. And the blubbery denizens are not shy about approaching divers.
"It's probably the most joyous, childlike diving I've ever done‚Äîlike getting in the water with 500 puppies," says Mann. "They're so curious and charismatic."
The dive was one of many highlights of Mann's trip to Juan Fern√°ndez, an archipelago of three islands teeming with endemic plants and animals ‚Äî including the seals, orange-feathered Juan Fern√°ndez firecrown hummingbirds, and two vulnerab‚Ä¶

author.name: Christina Nunez, Andy Mann, Kyle Roepke

entry.title: These destinations inspired the most popular video games
entry.summary: Valley of the Kings near Luxor, Egypt, is featured in popular video games such as Indiana Jones and the Great Circle and Assassin‚Äôs Creed: Origins, inspiring gamers to add the historic destination to their travel bucket list. Video game tourism is on the rise as the games‚Äô immersive and interactive worlds spark wanderlust in their biggest fans. From Oslo to Tokyo, here are eight places where gamers can level up. At least 35 percent of U.S. travelers are inspired to book a trip overseas based on a video game they've played, according to Skyscanner‚Äôs¬†recent survey As technology becomes more accessible and sophisticated, video games continue to gain points other traditional media can‚Äôt quite reach.¬†May Naidoo¬†is not surprised. He‚Äôs a filmmaker and Pok√©mon Partner w‚Ä¶

entry.title: Towel art has risen to a whole new level
entry.summary:
As any traveler can attest to, it‚Äôs the unique touches in hotel rooms and cruise cabins that make a trip that much more memorable. For both adults and children, there's nothing more uplifting than walking into your room to find a towel folded into the shape of a lovable animal. But how did the art form of origami make its way to the hospitality industry?
The history of origami is as complex as the intricately folded paper. Many scholars believe that the invention of paper in China, around 100 B.C.E., coincided with the first attempts at paper folding. It was the Japanese who made origami, originally known as orikata, a large part of their culture. Because paper was very expensive, the art form was mostly used for religious rituals by the wealthy, including wrapping offerings to the go‚Ä¶

entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: The American Trends Panel survey methodology Overview Data in this report comes from Wave 160 of the American Trends Panel (ATP), Pew Research Center‚Äôs nationally representative panel of randomly selected U.S. adults. The survey was conducted Jan. 8-19, 2025, among a sample of lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender and queer (LGBTQ) U.S. adults. entry.title: 5. Community, friends and LGBTQ spaces
entry.summary: We asked LGBTQ Americans some questions to better understand: Connections to a broader LGBTQ community About a quarter of LGBTQ adults (23%) say they feel extremely or very connected to a broader LGBTQ community. Another 42% feel somewhat connected, and 35% feel not too or not at all connected. Views on this vary by: How [‚Ä¶] The post 5. Community, friends and LGBTQ spaces appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 4. LGBTQ identities
entry.summary: To better understand how LGBTQ adults identify, we asked respondents three separate questions: When it comes to sexual orientation, more than half of LGBTQ adults (55%) describe themselves as bisexual. Four-in-ten are gay or lesbian, while small shares are straight (1%) or something else (3%). About one-in-ten LGBTQ adults (9%) are transgender. This includes 4% [‚Ä¶] The post 4. LGBTQ identities appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 3. Experiences with coming out as gay, lesbian, bisexual or transgender
entry.summary: To better understand the coming out experiences of gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender adults, we asked them: Half or more in each group say they knew they were gay, lesbian, bisexual or trans before age 14. Far fewer say they first told someone by that age. Small shares ranging from 1% to 4% across these [‚Ä¶] The post 3. Experiences with coming out as gay, lesbian, bisexual or transgender appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 2. Personal experiences with acceptance and discrimination
entry.summary: We asked LGBTQ adults whether they feel accepted by their family, friends and co-workers, and about their experiences with discrimination based on their LGBTQ identity. Some LGBTQ adults are not out to different people in their lives. Varying shares say no one in each of the following groups knows about their sexual orientation or gender [‚Ä¶] The post 2. entry.title: Ukraine: Hopes for peace on life support, Security Council hears
entry.summary: A glimmer of hope for peace in Ukraine has been overshadowed by a devastating new wave of Russian attacks, UN officials told the Security Council on Thursday, warning of soaring civilian casualties and a worsening humanitarian crisis that could derail a diplomatic end to the war.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN searches for solutions to global housing crisis
entry.summary: The UN‚Äôs urban development agency¬†estimates that an astonishing 2.8 billion people worldwide lack access to adequate housing, secure land, and basic water and sanitation services ‚Äì that‚Äôs around 40 per cent of the global population.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: ‚ÄòWe are the present‚Äô: Tajik climate activist urges leaders to include youth voices in dialogue
entry.summary: A young activist from Tajikistan is speaking up to show that her generation can be part of the solution to combat climate change.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Desperate hunger drives crowd to storm UN food warehouse in Gaza
entry.summary: Desperate hunger drove crowds of people to overrun a World Food Programme (WFP) warehouse in central Gaza on Wednesday, reportedly leaving two dead and several injured in a chaotic scramble for food.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN honours service and sacrifice of its peacekeepers
entry.summary: The United Nations is honouring staff serving at its field missions through several events to mark the International Day of UN Peacekeepers on Thursday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Winners revealed: National Geographic Traveller (UK) Photography Competition 2025
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
¬†Seeking to highlight the best in travel photography, this prestigious annual competition, celebrating its 12th year, was open to entrants from across the UK and Ireland. Photographers, both amateur and professional, submitted travel images taken during the past year in any of six categories: Landscape, People, Wildlife, Food, City life and Portfolio.¬†
Pat Riddell, editor of National Geographic Traveller (UK), said: ‚ÄúOur competition goes from strength to strength, with this year‚Äôs easily one of the strongest yet. World-class photography remains at the heart of the National Geographic brand, and the winners happily sit in that category.¬†
‚ÄúCapturing everything from the dramatic landscapes of Iceland and Italy to‚Ä¶

entry.title: Tips for Turning Unreadable Text Into Evidence
entry.summary: Whether it's extracting names from footage, decoding social media posts, or reading distorted text in documents, Henk van Ess explains how free digital tools can take on these investigative tasks.

entry.title: Video: How religious are young Americans today?
entry.summary: Young adults today are less religious than older adults by traditional measures. But when it comes to spirituality, the differences are smaller. The post Video: How religious are young Americans today? appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 9 celestial events lighting up the night sky this June
entry.summary:
Whether you‚Äôre waking up early to spot Venus in the pre-dawn sky, staying up late to peep the Lagoon Nebula, or spending the whole night on the hunt for meteors, June‚Äôs night sky has something for every stargazer. Here‚Äôs what to keep an eye out for when you look up this month.
(9 must-see night sky events to look forward to in 2025.)
On June 1, Venus will reach its farthest distance west of the sun from the perspective of Earth‚Äîa point known as greatest western elongation. This is a particularly good time to get a glimpse at Earth‚Äôs neighboring planet, as it won‚Äôt be drowned out by sunlight.
In some time zones, the exact timing of this event occurs on May 31, while in others, it's on June 1. But the best time to view Venus is just before dawn, when it rises in the eastern ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Need to unwind? This new travel trend adds a twist.
entry.summary:
Taking action to restore and care for nature sparks the brain‚Äôs reward circuits, fostering a lasting sense of purpose and connection. Wellness-centric travel has long been popular, with numerous health studies touting the benefits of spending more time in nature. A new evolution of the trend puts wildlife at the center‚Äîresponsibly.
In today‚Äôs fast-paced and tech-dominated world, people are plugged into the conveniences of modern day life, but they‚Äôre as disconnected as ever, overlooking the simple joys of nature and the wellness benefits it can offer us. You could say that the more high-tech we become, the more nature we undoubtedly need. The practice of forest bathing to cultivate relaxation and ward off the effects of stress and anxiety is well-established, but next-level nature ‚Ä¶

entry.title: These are the best stargazing sites in North America
entry.summary:
Both urban and rural areas are darkening their skies to boost astrotourism. These dark sky sanctuaries, reserves, parks, and trails invite you to immerse yourself in the wonders of our night skies. Here‚Äôs where to go.
Travelers are increasingly lifting their eyes to nighttime skies in search of impressive celestial phenomena and, perhaps, more. ‚ÄúLooking up at the night sky is sort of what makes us human,‚Äù says Ruskin Hartley, the executive director of DarkSky International, a nonprofit group based in Tucson, Arizona. ‚ÄúWe have done it for millennia. Every single culture has told their first stories in the stars overhead, and they found meaning in the stars. Today, the vast majority of people are robbed of that.‚Äù
On a clear night last November, I spent over two hours in a dome a‚Ä¶

entry.title: Explore the UK through its family-friendly summer festivals
entry.summary:
Sewing camps and sensory gardens will be at this year‚Äôs Camp Bestival. Music festivals in the UK are doing more than ever to cater to all interests and ages. Here are this summer‚Äôs family-friendly highlights.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Music festivals are doing more than ever to cater to all interests and ages. Younger audiences are often won over purely by the fact that attendance typically involves camping, glamping or pitching up in a caravan ‚Äî an opportunity to sleep out in the wild. But the UK‚Äôs best festivals also provide an endless roster of activities, workshops and experiences to help families bond and create lasting memories. From chilled countryside escapes to adrenaline-sparking coastal adventures. Here are the golden tickets‚Ä¶

entry.title: The world‚Äôs plastic pollution crisis, explained
entry.summary:
Plastic trash drifts in the ocean in the Philippines. Much of the planet is swimming in discarded plastic, which is harming animal and possibly human health. Can plastic pollution be cleaned up?
Plastic pollution has become one of the most pressing environmental issues, thanks to the overwhelming rise in production of disposable plastic products.
Plastic pollution is most visible in developing Asian and African nations, where garbage collection systems are often inefficient or nonexistent. But the developed world, especially in countries with low recycling rates, also has trouble properly collecting discarded plastics.
Plastic trash has become so ubiquitous it has prompted efforts to write a global treaty negotiated by the United Nations.
Plastics made from fossil ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Pandemics to pollution: WHO Assembly delivers landmark health decisions
entry.summary: The 78th World Health Assembly concluded Tuesday in Geneva, marking several major milestones in global health. Delegates adopted the world‚Äôs first pandemic agreement and approved a significant boost in core funding for the World Health Organization (WHO).

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Sudan war exacerbates risk of cholera and malaria: UNICEF
entry.summary: The UN Children‚Äôs Fund (UNICEF) has warned of an escalating public health crisis in Sudan, as conflict and mass displacement continue to drive a surge in disease, particularly cholera and malaria.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Yemen: UN warns against Houthi-Israel escalation, calls for dialogue
entry.summary: The United Nations has called for restraint following another wave of escalation between Houthi rebels in Yemen and Israeli forces.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN awards 2025 Mandela Prize to Brenda Reynolds and Kennedy Odede
entry.summary: An Indigenous¬†social worker from Canada and a social entrepreneur from Kenya are the laureates of the 2025 Nelson Rolihlahla Mandela Prize, the United Nations announced on Wednesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: ‚ÄòMy husband died in my arms‚Äô: Russian drone attacks on Ukrainians amount to crimes against humanity, UN investigators report
entry.summary: Russian drone attacks against civilians in the Kherson region of Ukraine constitute crimes against humanity and war crimes, independent UN human rights investigators concluded in a report published on Wednesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: ‚ÄòWe are women like you‚Äô: UN honours peacekeepers for work in gender empowerment
entry.summary: In early summer 2024, Squadron Leader Sharon Mwinsote Syme of Ghana ventured into sector North of Abyei, a disputed region between Sudan and South Sudan where she was deployed as a military gender advocate with the UN Interim Security Force in Abyei (UNISFA).

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza: Top UN envoy calls on Israel to end devastating strikes, starvation of civilians
entry.summary: Gaza‚Äôs population is being ‚Äústarved and denied the very basics,‚Äù while the region stands at a dangerous crossroads, the UN‚Äôs Middle East peace envoy warned the Security Council Wednesday, urging immediate action to halt the violence, restore aid and advance a two-State solution before time runs out.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN aid teams plead for access amid reports Gazans shot collecting food
entry.summary: In Gaza, dozens of Palestinians have been reportedly injured and shot trying to collect aid from the new US and Israeli-backed aid distribution facility operating independently of the UN.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Climate change: World likely to breach 1.5¬∞C limit in next five years
entry.summary: Fact: 2024 was the warmest year on record ‚Äì but the heat is far from over. A new report from the World Meteorological Organization (WMO) warns that global temperatures will likely continue rising, with an 80 per cent chance that at least one year between now and 2029 will be even hotter.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: How did this shark swim a record-breaking 4,000 miles?
entry.summary:
Bull sharks tend to be aggressive and live near shorelines, which has earned them fearsome reputations. One eight-foot-long female recently logged a record breaking 4,000-mile journey. Along her migration from Mozambique to Nigeria, the eight-foot-long female would have encountered a zone of water too cold to cross that has kept Africa's bull shark populations separated for 55,000 years.
When Turawa Hakeem caught a bull shark near Lagos, Nigeria last summer, the Ghanaian captain had no idea his crew was reeling a record winner onto his wooden fishing boat.
The eight-foot-long female had made an epic journey of at least 4,500 miles, the longest known movement of its species and the first time a bull shark was documented swimming through two oceans. The shark traveled from the M‚Ä¶

entry.title: Frozen shoulder is a real condition‚Äîand it mostly affects women
entry.summary:
Frozen shoulder is straightforward‚Äîthe condition means stiffness and difficulty in raising the arm. It can be caused by partial tears in the shoulder's tendon, as represented in this MRI scan. The painful affliction known as adhesive capsulitis can last for years‚Äîbut has long been ignored by medical researchers who doubted its existence. New treatments may finally promise a cure.
Stirrups, Pap smears, prenatal checks: At her busy office at Duke Women‚Äôs Health in Durham, NC, OB-GYN¬†Anne Ford‚Äôs work with female patients of all ages usually takes place from the waist down.
But Ford has noticed that a subset of her patients‚Äîall women entering or past menopause‚Äîcome to their appointments with a seemingly non-gynecological issue: adhesive capsulitis or ‚Äúfrozen shoulder,‚Äù a poorly un‚Ä¶

entry.title: These intimate safari camps offer a peek into Maasai culture
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
‚ÄúSimba!‚Äù The urgent whisper ‚Äî ‚Äòlion‚Äô in Swahili ‚Äî comes from Julius Naurori as he stands bolt upright in the back of our 4WD like a human antenna.
Immediately, our guide in the front slows the car to a cautious prowl and a hush descends, save for the tinkling silver discs tied to Julius‚Äôs waist as they sway in time with the rocking of the car. The dawn sky is still blushing crimson, and at first it‚Äôs hard to see what‚Äôs almost directly in front of us: four sleeping lions, their chocolate manes camouflaged as they lie on their sides in long, unruly grass marking the banks of the Mara River.
Our guide is Roca River Camp co-owner Ross Withey, and Julius, our wildlife-spotter, is his wingman on this safari drive in‚Ä¶

entry.title: These remote desert oases are Egypt‚Äôs hidden gems
entry.summary:
Siwa Oasis, a 12-hour drive from Cairo, is worth the trip to swim and float in hundreds of salt lakes and natural hot springs. Most visitors never experience the natural masterpieces that lie off the tourist trail‚Äîfrom bubbling hot springs to unearthly landscapes of dead volcanoes to the ‚ÄúValley of the Whales.‚Äù
The world knows Egypt for the Pyramids of Giza and cosmopolitan Cairo, the tourist-trodden temples of Luxor, and Red Sea resort towns. These coastal and Nile River Valley destinations are a narrow view of a country that‚Äôs 90 percent desert.
Few travelers venture into that 90 percent. The vast Western Desert, which blends into Libya and beyond, is Egypt‚Äôs great unknown. Adventurers since Alexander the Great have braved the harsh clime and been rewarded with the untouched‚Ä¶

entry.title: UN aims to transform urgency into action at Nice Ocean Conference
entry.summary: Countries are uniting in the French city of Nice next month to save the marine environment.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Exponential rise in synthetic drug production and trafficking in the Golden Triangle
entry.summary: The Golden Triangle ‚Äì the remote, jungle-covered border region where Thailand, Myanmar, and the Lao People‚Äôs Democratic Republic meet ‚Äì has seen an exponential surge in the illicit manufacture and trafficking of synthetic drugs.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Sanctions relief for Syria offers ‚Äòpowerful message of hope,‚Äô says UN migration agency
entry.summary: The UN International Organization for Migration (IOM) has welcomed recent decisions by the United States, the United Kingdom and the European Union to ease sanctions against Syria.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Sudan conflict triggers regional health crisis, warns WHO
entry.summary: As the war between rival militaries in Sudan continues, the World Health Organization (WHO) has raised alarm over the escalating health emergency, driven by ongoing violence, mass displacement, collapsing health systems and poor conditions inside refugee camps.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: New judge elected to the International Court of Justice
entry.summary: A seasoned diplomat and legal scholar from Jordan was elected on Tuesday to serve as a judge at the International Court of Justice (ICJ), the United Nations‚Äô principal judicial body.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Real cost of disasters is 10 times higher than previously thought, says UN
entry.summary: As countries face increasingly steep bills from natural hazards, the true cost of disasters is actually 10 times higher than previously estimated, with far-reaching effects across healthcare, housing, education and employment.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza: UN agencies calls for aid ‚Äòsurge‚Äô as Israeli distribution plan begins
entry.summary: Reports indicated on Tuesday that Israel‚Äôs controversial aid distribution plan had begun in Gaza as the United Nations called once again on the Israeli authorities to allow an ‚Äúimmediate surge‚Äù in the amount of supplies reaching the enclave to prevent starvation.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Marketplace for government agencies to buy all the personal data about Americans
entry.summary: For the Intercept, Sam Biddle reports on government plans for a one-stop shop‚Ä¶ Tags: Intercept, privacy

entry.title: Undisclosed surveillance with facial recognition in New Orleans
entry.summary: For The Washington Post, Douglas MacMillan and Aaron Schaffer report on a system‚Ä¶ Tags: facial recognition, privacy, Washington Post

entry.title: 8 of the best beach cities in Spain
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
High-spirited northern surf hubs, relaxed Mediterranean-fronting neighbourhoods and glowing sands washed by the thundering Atlantic ‚Äî mainland Spain‚Äôs cities can offer all of this and more. Take your pick of these varied urban beauties, scattered around the country‚Äôs 3,000-mile peninsular coast. Beaches in Spain can get packed everywhere during the high season, from July to August, so for the best chance of solitude and space, it‚Äôs worth travelling in the quieter shoulder periods.
A pair of wide gold beaches, tucked into a crescent-moon bay between forested headlands, sets the scene for one of northern Spain‚Äôs most popular coastal escapes. Many San Sebasti√°n strolls begin on the promenade curving past Playa de On‚Ä¶

entry.title: Are airline loyalty schemes worth it?
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
When British Airways (BA) launched its revamped frequent-flyer scheme on 1 April, it probably didn‚Äôt anticipate the furore that would follow. The new logo and name change ‚Äî a contraction from the Executive Club to simply the Club ‚Äî were uncontroversial. Instead, the outcry concerned the airline changing the way it plans to reward its customers.
Like most airline loyalty schemes, BA rewards its customers with two sets of points. The first, reward points ‚Äî¬†known as Avios in BA‚Äôs case ‚Äî are essentially an airline currency, and you can save these over months or years and redeem them for cheap flights and upgrades. The second, loyalty points, which BA calls Tier points, are collected over a single year and will move you‚Ä¶

entry.title: UN rights mission deplores deadly Russian strikes in Ukraine
entry.summary: The UN Human Rights Monitoring Mission in Ukraine (HRMMU) has deplored a deadly wave of Russian missile and drone strikes that reportedly killed at least 13 civilians and injured 65 others, warning that the attack underscores the grave risks of using powerful explosive weapons in populated areas.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Explore New Zealand one scenic drive at a time
entry.summary:
Life moves at a slower pace in New Zealand so taking your time while hitting the wide-open road is the best way to experience it. Starting from the country‚Äôs main gateways, such as Auckland and Christchurch, these road trips offer the best chance to experience the wealth and breadth of New Zealand‚Äôs unparalleled landscapes.
This article was produced by¬†National Geographic Traveller¬†(UK).
In Aotearoa (the MƒÅori name for New Zealand, which is often translated as ‚Äòthe land of the long white cloud‚Äô), life moves at a slower pace so taking your time while hitting the wide-open road is the best way to experience it. Meander through mountain ranges and past pancake rocks to wineries and whale-watching spots on New Zealand‚Äôs wild South Island, while on the North Island, take a leisur‚Ä¶

entry.title: Is Sasquatch real? Some Harrison Hot Springs residents say yes
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Henry Williams wasn‚Äôt always a believer in the Sasquatch. Growing up, he had of course heard the tales of old ‚Äî of a legendary hairy, bipedal primate said to roam the forests at sundown. Yet for much of his life, 76-year-old Henry had shrugged these stories off without much thought. They were used to remind youngsters to come home before nightfall, he‚Äôd reasoned. All that changed, however, on the day that the Sasquatch came to pay him a visit two decades ago, near his home in Squamish in southwest British Columbia.
‚ÄúIt threw a huge boulder into the middle of a nearby river,‚Äù says Henry, flinging his arms wide to imitate an almighty splash as we chat in the lobby of the Harrison Hot Springs Resort, a historic hotel ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Thousands flee homes in Mozambique as conflict and disasters fuel worsening crisis
entry.summary: More than 25,000 people have been forced to flee their homes in northern Mozambique in recent weeks, as conflict and a series of disasters fuel a worsening humanitarian crisis ‚Äì one that risks deepening as vital relief operations face a severe funding shortfall.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: 6 of the best rail adventures in British Columbia
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
British Columbia, Canada‚Äôs westernmost province, is well known for its spectacular landscapes, offering endless views of serrated peaks, opaline glacier lakes and feather-tipped pines. And what better way to take it all in than on a train, with those big-picture vistas slowly rolling by beyond the windowpanes ‚Äî here are some of the best rail routes to try.
Vancouver to Banff; 2 days This double-decker train is surely one of the world‚Äôs most scenic rail journeys, offering bubble-domed vistas of mountains, lakes, forests, gorges, rivers and glaciers and the chance to spot wildlife along the way. The classic First Passage to the West route follows part of the line from the historic Canadian Pacific Railway, Canada‚Äôs‚Ä¶

entry.title: Where to find Ireland's best food? Head west.
entry.summary:
Across County Cork‚Äôs wide and quiet expanse of gently rolling hills and craggy coastline, a culinary renaissance is unfolding, led by dairy farmers, foragers, fish smokers, and chefs. Here, Ireland‚Äôs soul and story are best understood on the plate.
Long overlooked on Europe‚Äôs gastronomic map, Ireland is emerging as a top culinary destination‚Äînowhere more so than in this rugged southwestern corner. County Cork's unique microclimate and creative community has served as fertile ground for culinary invention; and the hills are green nearly all year and shores are laden with seaweed superfoods. You‚Äôll find Michelin-starred restaurants hiding in villages of just a few hundred people, farmers crafting new kinds of cheese, and wild foragers bringing the native plants of Ireland back to palate‚Ä¶

entry.title: Why some people are better off sleeping on their sides
entry.summary:
If you struggle with sleep apnea, acid reflux, or back pain, changing how you sleep may offer some relief. Your sleep position can cause everything from back pain to acid reflux. A simple change can improve your health dramatically.
In recent years, a preponderance of research has shown that something as simple as sleeping on your side may be the answer to reducing back pain, heartburn, and sleep apnea‚Äîconditions that affect tens of millions of people‚Äîeven if it doesn‚Äôt also provide relief to some other issues people think it does.
‚ÄúSide sleeping does have clear benefits over stomach or back sleeping, but only for certain groups of individuals,"¬†says Raj Dasgupta, a pulmonary and sleep medicine physician at Huntington Memorial Hospital in California.
Here's what to know ‚Ä¶

entry.title: See Lake Como and the Italian Riviera without the crowds
entry.summary: Travelers looking for la dolce vita or the sweet life in Italy should consider a visit to the picturesque town of Menaggio on Lake Como. The three uniquely different towns of Rapallo, Varenna, and Menaggio offer elegant views, food tours and everything you need for your dream vacation. Most world travelers are familiar with the popular and often over-touristed cities in Italy such as Rome, Florence, Milan, and Naples, but there are lesser-known locales found on the Italian Riviera and in the Lake Como area that offer equally authentic experiences in Italian food, art, and cultural history. Here‚Äôs how to plan your dream Italian holiday to three towns in Northwest Italy‚Äîwithout the crowds. Situated on the coast of the Ligurian Sea just south of Genoa and north of Cinque‚Ä¶

entry.title: Quebec City offers the charm of Paris without the crowds
entry.summary:
Craving the romance of Paris without the jet lag or legions of other people? The City of Light welcomed nearly 30 million visitors in 2023, and even more admirers plan to travel there since the 2024 Summer Olympics and reopening of the Cathedral of Notre Dame. Canada‚Äôs Qu√©bec City, a UNESCO World Heritage Site with French roots, emanates European elegance yet welcomes about a fraction¬†of the visitors as Paris. Flights from the United States clock much shorter times too, providing travelers with Old World charm minus the travel fatigue. ¬†
French, British, and North American cultures weave together in this walkable, refined city. ‚ÄúQu√©bec City is French-speaking, but it‚Äôs North American, and it‚Äôs unique,‚Äù says David Mendel, an author and historian who has lived in Paris and has also resi‚Ä¶

entry.title: See Sally Ride‚Äôs boundary-breaking life in photos
entry.summary:
When pioneering female astronaut Sally Ride died of pancreatic cancer in 2012, a single line in her obituary told the story a lifetime of press coverage and fame had never revealed: her 27-year partnership with another woman, Tam O‚ÄôShaughnessy.
The revelation that Ride was a member of the LGBTQ+ community added another first to her lengthy list of historic accomplishments. She was not just the first American woman to go to space‚Äî41 years ago on June 18, 1983‚Äîbut the first known queer astronaut.
The revelation added a new dimension to the intense, brilliant physicist, loyal crew member, and passionate science education advocate. And it led some to question what Ride‚Äôs life may have been like in a less homophobic, sexist world. Ride‚Äôs private journey is uncovered in the award-winni‚Ä¶

Appendix: AI keywords used in this study
entry.summary: A webpage was classified as containing an AI mention if it had at least one of the following keywords. These keywords were detected using regular expression matching, included common variants and were not case sensitive, unless noted otherwise. The post Appendix: AI keywords used in this study appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: The findings in this report are based on an analysis of the browsing behaviors of 900 U.S. adults who are members of the KnowledgePanel Digital online panel, a subset of Ipsos‚Äô KnowledgePanel. These panelists qualified for the study because they: After the March monitoring period, panelists‚Äô web browsing activity logs were delivered on April 7, [‚Ä¶] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: What Web Browsing Data Tells Us About How AI Appears Online
entry.summary: One month of web browsing data shows most respondents visited a search page with an AI-generated summary, but visits to in-depth content about AI were much rarer. The post What Web Browsing Data Tells Us About How AI Appears Online appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Why cancer rates are rising in young women‚Äîand what to do about it
entry.summary:
A PET scan of a female patient with breast cancer, which has spread to the lymph nodes, bones and liver. A recent report found that women account for two-thirds of all cancers diagnosed in people under 50. But it's not all bad news.
In its recent annual report, the American Cancer Society shared some striking news: Cancer is turning up more frequently in young people ‚Äì especially in young women.¬†
Before we panic: The trend is not entirely a new one. Women have long had higher cancer rates than men in younger age groups. And there‚Äôs good news in the report too, says Otis Brawley, an oncologist and epidemiology professor at Johns Hopkins University‚Äôs Bloomberg School of Public Health. Namely, it found that, overall, cancer deaths have been trending downward.
But the report‚Ä¶

entry.title: Been to Barcelona? Now try Spain's lesser-known cities
entry.summary:
Stay a few days to roam the sloping Albaic√≠n district, where locals and visitors gather on broad terraces to catch views across terracotta rooftops to the Alhambra, backed by the spectacular Sierra Nevada mountains. Watch flamenco, roam medieval streets and find local tapas haunts in these destination dupes.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
With Spain receiving record-breaking numbers of international visitors in the past two years ‚Äî up to 94 million last year ‚Äî it pays to hunt out its quiet corners. And there are plenty of areas where travellers have yet to claim a stake. While major Spanish cities like Barcelona, Madrid and Seville justifiably receive millions of visitors a year, the country is packed with dozens of disarmingly beautiful and‚Ä¶

entry.title: Why Tateyama Kurobe route is Japan‚Äôs ultimate mountain journey
entry.summary:
The journey on Tateyama Kurobe Alpine Route involves travelling by train, bus, funicular, cable car and even a short stretch on foot. This multimodal route through the country‚Äôs Northern Alps is a great alternative to the similar journey around Mount Fuji ‚Äî and one which attracts far fewer visitors.
This article was produced by¬†National Geographic Traveller¬†(UK).
For travellers looking to explore the peaks of Japan, it doesn‚Äôt get much better than the Tateyama Kurobe Alpine Route, an extraordinary expedition through the country‚Äôs Northern Alps in the centre of the main island of Honshu. Like a similar but far more travelled route around Mount Fuji to the south,¬†this itinerary incorporates multiple forms of transport ‚Äî a train, funicular, highland bus, cable car and electric ‚Ä¶

entry.title: How one young pharaoh turned Egypt into a superpower
entry.summary:
The death of Queen Hatshepsut opened the door to rebellion in the Levant. After 22 years in power, she disappeared from history and Thutmose III occupied the throne of Egypt alone. A coalition of Canaanite city-states, supported by the Mitanni Empire and rulers of Kadesh, began to rebel against the new pharaoh. It would come to a head in the walled city of Megiddo, in what today is Israel. Sited on the Plain of Esdraelon, the city could control two trade routes of special interest: one connecting with the coastline and the other leading north to Kadesh. As this was Thutmose‚Äôs first military campaign, the pressure on him was considerable.
According to the large propaganda inscription on the walls of Akh Menu (the Temple of Thutmose III at Karnak), the young pharaoh gathered his m‚Ä¶

entry.title: UNHCR underscores plight of Rohingya refugees amid alarming reports
entry.summary: The UN refugee agency (UNHCR) on Friday released a¬†statement expressing grave concern over reports that two boats carrying Rohingya refugees sank off the coast of Myanmar earlier this month, with an estimated 427 people dead.

entry.title: Diplomats prepare ground for June conference on two-State solution for Israel and Palestine
entry.summary: Diplomats convened at UN Headquarters in New York on Friday to lay the groundwork for a crucial international conference in June, aimed at advancing global efforts towards achieving a two-State solution to the Israel-Palestine conflict.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Escalating violence drives food crisis across eastern DR Congo, warns WFP
entry.summary: As violence intensifies in eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC), the World Food Programme (WFP)¬†warned Friday that food insecurity is worsening both within the country and in neighbouring States, where 140,000 Congolese have fled since January.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN rights chief calls on South Sudan‚Äôs warring parties to end renewed fighting
entry.summary: The UN on Friday warned of further deterioration in the human rights situation in South Sudan amid an uptick in hostilities, arbitrary arrests and hate speech since February.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Guterres calls on Israel to accept UN‚Äôs ‚Äòdetailed, principled‚Äô aid plan for Gaza
entry.summary: The UN Secretary-General on Friday outlined a five-stage plan to provide lifesaving aid to the stricken population of Gaza, making clear the organization will not take part in any scheme that fails to respect international law or basic humanitarian principles.

entry.title: Syrians face staggering needs amid insecurity and healthcare crisis
entry.summary: Millions of people in Syria continue to face mortal danger from unexploded munitions, disease and malnutrition and more international support is urgently required, senior UN aid officials said on Friday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Aid teams highlight growing anxiety in Gaza after food is looted
entry.summary: Long-awaited food supplies have been looted in Gaza overnight while being transported to desperate communities in the war-torn enclave, UN aid teams reported on Friday.

entry.title: In search of ‚Äòfjaka‚Äô‚Äîthe Croatian art of doing nothing
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
This story begins ‚Äî as many good yarns do ‚Äî in a bar. Specifically, Beach Bar Dodo beside Dubrovnik‚Äôs seafront, where I‚Äôm sipping beer with a friend. David Farley had sub-let his perfectly nice flat in New York to decamp to Croatia. What‚Äôs he doing with his days, I ask. Not much, he replies: ‚ÄúPerfecting my fjaka.‚Äù
Fjaka, pronounced ‚Äòfee-aka‚Äô, could only have come from a land of sunbaked islands. It is, David explains, no place to go, no place to be. Allowing days to drift and blur. Back in the capital, Zagreb, they make rude jokes about Dalmatians as donkeys, but that misses the point entirely. With fjaka, the region has elevated easy living into an artform.
With no better plans, I decide to embark on a quixot‚Ä¶

entry.title: Going to the beach is good for your brain, according to science
entry.summary:
There's little more relaxing than spending time at the beach‚Äîbut what's going on in your brain during a day spent playing in the waves? Scientists are discovering more of the benefits of "blue spaces" like the coast. Visiting the coast can help you relieve stress and get more active‚Äîand it may even change the way you cope with pain.
The coast has long been a place of healing. In 18th-century Europe, doctors prescribed beach time for ailments ranging from tuberculosis to leprosy. Patients spent their days bathing in (and often drinking) mineral-rich sea water, and at night, they fell asleep to the sounds of briny winds and crashing waves.
While elements of this early sea therapy have since been disproven, modern science continues to find that nature is good for us. Researchers ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Do dolphins have a language? Scientists are finding new clues.
entry.summary:
Bottlenose dolphins living near Sarasota, Florida have been observed making consistently structured whistles that suggest a common meaning. ‚ÄúIf there is a species that we might be able to engage with in some kind of two-way communication, these guys are really good candidates.‚Äù
Dolphins are some of the most vocal animals in our oceans. Their pods are a bustling soundscape of clicks, whistles, and buzzy pulses. What to our ears is a creaking door or a melodic pop is to a dolphin a means to echolocate or communicate.
They even have names‚Äîresearch has found they use ‚Äòsignature whistles‚Äô to identify themselves, a sort of vocal version of a human‚Äôs signature. These whistles are produced by one individual and repeated by another‚Äî‚ÄúJeff, Jeff‚Äù‚Äîto initiate or re-establish contact. The ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Uncovering Williamsburg and the Historic Triangle
entry.summary:
The clang of a blacksmith at work, historical reenactments and tours, beautiful scenic drives, and outdoor adventure‚Äîthere‚Äôs nothing quite like Williamsburg, Virginia, no matter the season.¬†
History is present and alive in the rhythm of the Historic Triangle: Colonial Williamsburg, Jamestown, and Yorktown. National Geographic Photographer Greg Kahn recently traveled to this all-American region to capture this experience through the quiet, sensory details that shape memory: the clack of a horse's hoof, the flicker of firelight in a blacksmith‚Äôs shop, the lap of a wave as it hits a sandy shore. It's all here in Williamsburg. undefined undefined undefined undefined In Colonial Williamsburg, the Fifes and Drums Corps preserves the powerful rhythms of 18th-century mili‚Ä¶

entry.title: Do fish sleep? Here‚Äôs what scientists have discovered so far
entry.summary:
A protective mucous cocoon surrounds this parrotfish as it sleeps in Australia's Great Barrier Reef. This layer of protection helps fend off predators so parrotfish can get a good night's rest. Sleep in fish may look different from humans, but rest is essential for survival. Here‚Äôs what experts have to say about fish sleep.
  If you‚Äôve ever gone snorkeling on a coral reef during the day, you likely saw waves of brightly colored fish of all shapes and sizes. But return to the same spot in the middle of the night, and most of those same creatures will have vanished.¬† Which might make one wonder, do fish¬†sleep¬†? ‚Ä¶

entry.title: 10 of the best hotels in Prague
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
It might be the medieval architecture or the riverside setting, the youthful atmosphere or ‚Äî arguably ‚Äî the world‚Äôs best beer. Whatever the reason, the Czech capital is a perennial favourite. The good news is that the shortfall in rooms of a decade ago is no longer an issue. Plenty of new hotels have opened, standards have risen and prices have moderated. Properties in the central Old Town feature historic settings and period details. For an authentic local feel, consider one of Prague‚Äôs residential quarters, like elegant Vinohrady or artsy Hole≈°ovice. Wherever you decide to stay, efficient public transport is always close at hand to whisk you about.
Best for: fashionistas The long-awaited reopening of the ar‚Ä¶

entry.title: How to plan the ultimate Trans-Canadian Highway road trip
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Stretching from coast to coast, the Trans-Canada Highway is a ribbon of road that stitches together the vast landscapes of Canada, from the glacier lakes of Alberta to the prairies of Manitoba. But it‚Äôs the British Columbia section that arguably shines brightest, offering a wealth of experiences across some 500 miles.
The real charm of driving this route is watching the scenery beyond the windscreen switch from lush rainforest to the rugged Rocky Mountains. Take your time: six days is ideal, pausing to uncover the mysteries of old ghost towns, delve into the region‚Äôs Chinese heritage, or experience the thrill of whitewater rafting. Each stop offers a new perspective on Canada‚Äôs wild western frontier.
The adv‚Ä¶
